> 
> And by all two (2) of Max' posts in that thread you can deduct that they're cutting corners all over the place.

I won't say it's made me think they're "cutting corners all over the place" but it does strongly imply they are not able to do what they were hoping in the apparently esoterically divined time frame they've set, and are therefore looking to find the minimum number of corners to cut. And it does seem to be that they're also looking all over the place for potential cuts.

The term, "matrix" and the phrases, "no dependencies between nodes" and, "all nodes have the exact same cost" made me wonder if anyone has suggested the idea of a purchase multiplier?

My (barely formed) idea is that all nodes are available at the start without cost. A purchase into any node raises the cost of the next purchase by some linear progression. Each node, however, has a multiplier attached based on how "powerful" or "advanced" or "part generous" the technology in it might be (or a combination: number of parts \* part generation \* invention level). The first purchase into the most advanced tech would be cheap, sure, but you'd be paying a higher amount for simpler tech later on because of it.

It might make one think about where to spend each time because costs go up regardless.

I've no idea if this is even feasible. I just wanted to get this out there before I forgot. Even if it has no merit, I figured it'd be a fund discussion topic. Feel free to shoot it down. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

> 
> I think once you get enough reputation, you should be able to propose your own missions and mission control will offer you money based on planet/difficulty/etc. Fits right into the existing system and would be a lot more fun.
> 
> 
> > 
> > I'd like to see something like science hotspots that you can find by yourself once you have the technology. Orbital scans might reveal the course location, you'd find the detailed locations on the ground. Some could be set and permanent, others might appear and disappear with time. Your scientists might give pointers to help you in the right direction, E.G travel in the direction that makes [sensor readings A & B] increase, but it's up to you to actually find them, putting you in the role of planet investigator.
> 
> 
> +1 Plus it would give the player incentive to explore planets (which is completely lacking atm). 
> 
> I also believe that splitting up tech vs science would be a great step in making science and visiting planets interesting. Tech are the parts which you'll have to unlock by paying and then testing flying them. Science is what you learn about planets/the universe, e.g. what height does the atmosphere end, what is the gravity of the heavenly bodies, how much delta V does it take to get to orbit (fits in nice with the upcoming delta V report), how old are planets/impact craters, where are resources located (sat for general indication, ground work for specific location), etc. All the while increasing planet resolution and info as you gain knowledge to more effectively plan your missions. Combine this with TW1's suggestion above and i think we'd actually have a fun career mode and this also fits in nicely with the current in-game modules.

> 
> Proposing your own missions would require a complex new system, I just don't see that happening. In addition, there are finite choices the game would care about unless they do even more work (all that matters is biomes, plus whatever mechanism regolith uses to randomize resources).

How specific can you get with Mod generated missions?

So long as you can designate the activity and the coordinates of check-point(s), it seems like it should be reasonably doable to make a mod where you could have buttons like 'designate landing site' that will generate a mission to land on the surface under your current location and make a crew report, with rewards based on the science multiplier for the body in question.

Other buttons could include 'Station/Satellite in low/polar/geo orbit' '[science] on surface/in flight(high/low)/in orbit' etc.

I'm not sure how difficult that would be, but it seems like all the data should be present for those to work...

And the 'you need a new craft after you accept the mission' should prevent just spamming the buttons to get all the science and funds you could ever want from the launch pad.

With the per-game modable tech tree, you could even generate 'test tech X' missions for all currently researchable tech, and reward the player by reducing the cost of that branch as part of the reward(which may have been artificially inflated to account for this discount). Not sure if that would require loading the game before you see the effects though...

One of the great things about a game that supports Mods well is that you need not rely on the developers to add in any specific content that you want. Especially with an active Mod community.
